courseTitle: Dehydration of an Inorganic Salt Hydrate

pageData.titleName2: Dehydration of an Inorganic Salt Hydrate

pageData.text: Students will use heat to quantitatively determine the stoichiometric ratio of water to inorganic salt in a salt <button class='glossary-text'>hydrate</button>.

pageData.title: Overview Video: Dehydration of an Inorganic Salt Hydrate

text: Explain how heating allows the water content of a <button class='glossary-text'>hydrate</button> to be determined.
Determine the molar ratio of water to inorganic salt in Epsom salt.
Demonstrate how to balance the chemical equation of the decomposition of a hydrate.

pageData.text: Gas <button class='glossary-text'>hydrates</button> are a crystalline solid that contains water and gas. You may look at a gas hydrate and think it is ice due to its appearance, but it contains huge amounts of methane. It is a common natural occurrence; gas hydrates have been found on every continent and beneath the sea floor. Gas hydrates are notoriously difficult to study because they are not stable at normal sea-level pressures and temperatures. Some scientists claim that the deposits found beneath the sea floor can lead to landmass collapses and landslides because these gas hydrates alter the sea floor sediment stability. There are also concerns that these gas hydrates can influence the environment and climate due to the contribution of methane to greenhouse gases. However, there may be benefits as well. Methane, which again is stored in high quantities in gas hydrates, contains more than twice the carbon of all fossil fuels combined. And because gas hydrates are found on each continent, these resources are evenly distributed around the world. Studies have discovered potential for gas hydrates in energy production and researchers continue to explore this resource.

pageData.desc: Several ice-cube-like pieces of gas hydrate on fire.
pageData.altText: Several ice-cube-like pieces of gas hydrate on fire.

pageData.text: The ability to balance chemical equations is an essential skill for understanding chemical reactions. Balanced equations are necessary to calculate the appropriate amounts of that are needed for specific reactions, and to determine the amount of that can be produced in a given chemical reaction. A chemical equation is a visual representation of a chemical reaction, and it is written much like a mathematical equation. A balanced chemical equation contains reactants that are combined to produce one or more new product(s). Instead of the equal sign that would be used in a mathematical equation, an arrow links the left side of the equation containing reactants with the right side of the equation containing product(s). The arrow indicates the primary direction of the reaction; double-headed arrows indicate reversible reactions. A simple chemical equation can be written as follows:A + B ➝ ABReactants ➝ Products

The states that mass is neither created nor destroyed during ordinary (i.e., non-nuclear) chemical reactions or physical changes. are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical reaction. The changes that occur during any chemical reaction are rearrangements of the atoms in the reactants.An atom is the smallest unit of an that retains the chemical properties of that element. An element is a pure substance that contains only one type of atom. A is a substance that contains two or more elements. A is the smallest unit of a compound that retains the chemical properties of that compound.

The same numbers of of each are present before and after a chemical reaction. This is represented by the balanced chemical equation. To achieve a balanced equation, numbers (called ) are placed before the element or symbol in the equation. Coefficients indicate the number of molecules or atoms that are involved in the reaction. indicate the number of atoms of a particular element in a molecule.

pageData.desc: Sample formula: 2 H sub 2 + O sub 2 renders 2 H sub 2 O. The first part of the formula (before renders) are the reactants. The resulting part are the products. The numbers 2 in (2 H) is called the coefficient. The sub numbers in H sub 2 and O sub 2 are called subscripts.
pageData.altText: Sample formula: 2 H sub 2 + O sub 2 renders 2 H sub 2 O. The first part of the formula (before renders) are the reactants. The resulting part are the products. The numbers 2 in (2 H) is called the coefficient. The sub numbers in H sub 2 and O sub 2 are called subscripts.

pageData.text: A chemical equation is unbalanced if the number of atoms of each element on the left () and right () sides of the equation are not equal. An unbalanced chemical equation does not obey the , and does not accurately represent the chemical reaction.

pageData.question: Which statement best describes the Law of Conservation of Mass?

options.text: Mass is neither created nor destroyed during ordinary chemical reactions or physical changes.
Mass is created, not destroyed, during ordinary chemical reactions or physical changes.
Mass is destroyed when a substance undergoes a physical change.
Mass is neither created nor destroyed during nuclear chemical reactions.
Mass is created during ordinary chemical reactions as an equivalent amount of another mass is destroyed.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The Law of Conservation of Mass states that mass is neither created nor destroyed during ordinary (i.e., non-nuclear) chemical reactions or physical changes.

pageData.question: Which of the following confirms a chemical equation obeys the Law of Conservation of Mass?

options.text: The equation is balanced.
The reaction arrow is in the forward direction.
There are no elements in the equation.
The equation was determined experimentally.
There are an equal number of products as reactants in the equation.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A chemical equation must be balanced for it to obey the Law of Conservation of Mass.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The Law of Conservation of Mass states that mass is neither created nor destroyed during ordinary (i.e., non-nuclear) chemical reactions or physical changes. Atoms are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical reaction. The changes that occur during any chemical reaction are rearrangements of the atoms in the reactants. The same numbers of atoms of each element are present before and after a chemical reaction. This is represented by the balanced chemical equation. A chemical equation is unbalanced if the number of atoms of each element on the left (reactant) and right (product) sides of the equation are not equal. An unbalanced chemical equation does not obey the Law of Conservation of Mass and does not accurately represent the chemical reaction.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The Law of Conservation of Mass states that mass is neither created nor destroyed during ordinary (i.e., non-nuclear) chemical reactions or physical changes. Atoms are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical reaction. The changes that occur during any chemical reaction are rearrangements of the atoms in the reactants. The same numbers of atoms of each element are present before and after a chemical reaction. This is represented by the balanced chemical equation. A chemical equation is unbalanced if the number of atoms of each element on the left (reactant) and right (product) sides of the equation are not equal. An unbalanced chemical equation does not obey the Law of Conservation of Mass and does not accurately represent the chemical reaction.

pageData.text: A <button class='glossary-text'>hydrate</button> is a particular type of <button class='glossary-text'>molecule</button>, such as an inorganic salt, which contains water integrated into a solid crystalline structure. A common example of a hydrate is copper sulfate pentahydrate, which has five (penta-) water molecules associated with one copper sulfate molecule. The molecular formula of copper sulfate pentahydrate is CuSO<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub> · 5H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O. The dot in the molecular formula is used specifically to indicate that the molecule is a hydrate in the solid form. A hydrate will only exist as a solid; hydration occurs during the process of crystallization, and the hydrate typically dissociates during a chemical reaction. An inorganic salt and its hydrate have different physical characteristics. Typically, a hydrate and its anhydrous counterpart will have different colors, textures, and/ or consistency. Figure 1 compares the visual appearance of anhydrous (without water) copper sulfate on the left, with copper sulfate pentahydrate on the right.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Photo comparing anhydrous copper sulfate as a white powder (left) with the hydrated copper sulfate a blue crystal (right).
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Photo comparing anhydrous copper sulfate as a white powder (left) with the hydrated copper sulfate a blue crystal (right).

pageData.text: From an experimental perspective, a is interesting because it can be used for a straightforward analysis of stoichiometric ratios and molecular formula. Copper sulfate pentahydrate has a very specific ratio of 5 water to 1 copper sulfate molecule. This ratio can be determined experimentally with a high degree of certainty. First, a sample of copper hydrate pentahydrate is weighed. The sample is then heated over a Bunsen burner or in a drying oven to remove the water, as shown in the following balanced chemical equation:(CuSO4 · 5H2O)solid + Heat ➝ (CuSO4)solid + 5H2OgasA drying oven is typically used if finer temperature control is required to prevent the inorganic salt from decomposing due to excessive heat. Once the heated sample has cooled, it is weighed again. The mass difference between the initial sample weight and the final sample weight is equal to the mass of evaporated water.Mass — Massfinal = Masswater4.98 g — 3.18 g = 1.80 g

In this example, 3.18 g is the mass of anhydrous copper sulfate recovered after heating, and 1.80 g is the mass of water that evaporated from the sample. These two numbers can be used to calculate the molar ratios of copper sulfate and water in copper sulfate pentahydrate. The next step in determining the molar ratios is to convert the calculated grams of copper sulfate and water to moles. mass (g) "molar" mass ( g mol ) = moles 3.18 g 159.61 g/mol = 0.0199 moles copper sulfate 1.80 g 18.02 g/mol = 0.0999 moles waterThe molar mass of a substance can be calculated using the atomic mass of each in the substance. The atomic mass of each element is given on the periodic table. The atomic mass of copper is 63.55 g/mol, sulfur is 32.06 g/mol, and oxygen is 16.00 g/mol. The molar mass for copper sulfate is calculated by adding the atomic masses for one copper, one sulfur, and four oxygen .

63.55 + 32.06 + (4 × 16.00) = 159.61The molar mass of any can be calculated in this way. The molar ratio of water to copper sulfate can then be calculated as follows. Divide the moles of water by the moles of copper sulfate. The ratio of water to copper sulfate is calculated as 5.02; because the number of water molecules in a are integers, 5.02 can be rounded to 5. moles water moles copper sulfate = 0.0999 0.0199 = 5.02 = 5 moles water ∶ 1 mole copper sulfateIn this activity, you will determine the water ratio in Epsom salt, which is a hydrate of magnesium sulfate (MgSO4). Samples of Epsom salt will be dried over a flame, and the change in sample mass will help you determine the ratio of water to magnesium sulfate in the sample. The molar mass of anhydrous magnesium sulfate is 120.37 g/mol.

pageData.question: Amanda is conducting an experiment to determine the moles of water in an inorganic salt hydrate. After heating the sample, 7.96 g of anhydrous copper sulfate and 0.8 g of water were recovered. Calculate the moles of water that evaporated in the experiment given the molar mass of water is 18.02 g/mol and the balanced chemical equation below.(CuSO4 · 5 H2O) solid + Heat ➝ (CuSO4) solid + 5 H2O gas

options.text: 0.04 mol
9.95 mol
0.16 mol
14.4 mol
0.8 mol

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text:
moles = mass (g) / molar mass (g/mol)
moles = 0.8 g / 18.02 g/mol
moles = 0.04439512 mol = 0.04 mol water

pageData.question:
What is the molar ratio of water to anhydrous salt, given the following data?Moles of water = 1.18 mol
Moles of anhydrous salt = 0.5 mol

options.text: 1 moles water: 4 moles salt
2 moles water: 1 mole salt
3 moles water: 2 moles salt
1.18 moles water: ½ mole salt
1 mole water: 1 mole salt

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text:
The molar ratio of water to anhydrous salt can be calculated by dividing the moles of water by the moles of salt.1.18 mol of water / 0.5 mol CuSO4 = 2.36
2 moles water: 1 mole salt

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. Before starting the activity, prepare a heatresistant work area. To start the activity, number the three aluminum dishes and add Epsom salt to each dish. Then, determine the mass of the salt in each dish. Next, light a Sterno® heater and place the heater under a wire stand. Heat each dish, then determine the mass of the dehydrated salt in each dish. Finally, calculate the mass of water, moles of magnesium sulfate, and moles of water in each sample, as well as the molar ratio of water to magnesium sulfate.
pageData.altText: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. Before starting the activity, prepare a heatresistant work area. To start the activity, number the three aluminum dishes and add Epsom salt to each dish. Then, determine the mass of the salt in each dish. Next, light a Sterno® heater and place the heater under a wire stand. Heat each dish, then determine the mass of the dehydrated salt in each dish. Finally, calculate the mass of water, moles of magnesium sulfate, and moles of water in each sample, as well as the molar ratio of water to magnesium sulfate.

pageData.text: Reorder Information:Replacement supplies for the Dehydration of an Inorganic Salt Hydrate investigation can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company, kit 580362.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Wear your safety goggles and gloves at all times while conducting this investigation.

Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in the Safety and Activity sections.

Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> contains flammable alcohol gel. Long hair must be tied back and loose clothing and papers must be kept away from the open flame. The Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can will stay hot even after the flame is extinguished. The Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can must be placed on a heatresistant surface, such as a stove top or trivet, while performing this activity.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area thoroughly with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What does the dot in the molecular formula of a hydrate indicate?

options.text: The molecule is a hydrate when in solid form.
The molecule is a hydrate when in liquid form.
The number of salt molecules should be multiplied by the number of water molecules.
The number of salt molecules should be divided by the number of water molecules.
The molecule only exists when dissolved in water.

assestmentData.question: Match each hydrate formula with its name.

options.text: CuSO<sub>4</sub> · 5 H<sub>2</sub>O
FeCl<sub>2</sub> · 4 H<sub>2</sub>O
MnSO<sub>4</sub> · H<sub>2</sub>O
NiCl<sub>2</sub> · 2 H<sub>2</sub>O
NiCl<sub>2</sub> · 6 H<sub>2</sub>O

assestmentData.question: Alisha is working in a chemistry lab. Her procedure calls for anhydrous cobalt chloride. She finds two bottles of cobalt chloride in the storeroom – a half-used bottle containing a purple powder and an unopened bottle containing a pale blue powder. Which bottle of cobalt chloride should she use and why?

options.text: The new bottle; it has not reacted with water in the air, unlike the purple salt.
The new bottle; it is a hydrate, unlike the purple salt.
The half-used bottle; it is a hydrate, unlike the blue salt.
The half-used bottle; it has not reacted with water in the air, unlike the blue salt.
The new bottle; it contains more salt than the other bottle.

assestmentData.question: If 10 grams of Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>PO<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub> · 12 H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O are heated until all the water has been driven off, how much should the remaining anhydrous salt weigh?
Given the following data, how many water molecules are associated with each molecule of zinc sulfate (ZnSO4)?Starting weight: 10 gDried weight: 5.52 g
Which of the following best describes the structure of a hydrate?

options.text: A crystalline structure with incorporated water molecules.
Bubble-like structures suspended in water.
Long chains attracted to one another by surrounding water molecules.
Sheet-like layers alternating with layers of water molecules.
A random structure dissolved in water.

assestmentData.question: The anhydrous analogs of some hydrated salts are packaged and used as desiccants to keep bottled chemicals dry. Which of the following best explains why an anhydrous salt is useful for this purpose?

options.text: The anhydrous salt will readily accept moisture from the surrounding environment.
The anhydrous salt will repel water if any is spilled on the packaging.
The anhydrous salt will change color when wet to indicate contamination by water.
The anhydrous salt will destroy any water molecules in the surrounding environment.
The anhydrous salt will convert gaseous water into liquid water.

assestmentData.question: The materials provided for this investigation include a Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> heater. Which of the following steps regarding lab attire is most applicable to the safe use of this heater?

options.text: Tie back long hair and avoid wearing loose clothing.
Wear gloves soaked in water.
Take off the safety goggles when lighting the heater.
Wear closed-toe shoes while the heater is lit.
Wear two pairs of gloves simultaneously.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the entire procedure before getting started.
Clear a work area for all lab materials.

The work area should be heat-resistant, such as a stove top or trivet, because the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can will get very hot during the activity and will remain hot even after the flame is extinguished.

The Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> heater will get extremely hot as the activity progresses. It is important to select a suitable heat-resistant working area so you do not need to move the can. Keep the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> lid and oven mitts or tongs close by in case they are needed. The Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> lid can be placed over the flame to immediately extinguish the flame. Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can be relit if accidently extinguished.
In this activity, you will heat a sample of Epsom salt, a <button class='glossary-text'>hydrate</button> of magnesium sulfate, to determine the ratio of water to magnesium sulfate in the sample.
Label the aluminum dishes 1, 2, and 3 as pictured in Figure 2.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Photo of aluminum weighing dish with sample number written on tab
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Photo of aluminum weighing dish with sample number written on tab

pageData.text: Weigh the aluminum dish labeled 1 on the balance and record the value in Data Table 1.
Measure approximately 0.3–0.8 g of Epsom salt in the aluminum dish and record the mass of the aluminum dish + Epsom salt in Data Table 1.
Subtract the mass of the empty aluminum dish 1 from the mass of the aluminum dish + Epsom salt. Record this value as “Epsom salt, original () mass” in Data Table 1.
Repeat steps 2–4 for the aluminum dishes numbered 2 and 3.
Open the lid of the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can; a flathead screwdriver or a key works best.
Note: Once lit, the Sterno® can has a 45-minute burn time. Be prepared to work all the way through the procedure to completion once lit.
Light the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can with matches or a lighter.
Slide the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can underneath the supplied wire stand.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Photo of aluminum weighing dish being placed on wire stand with forceps above Sterno® can
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Photo of aluminum weighing dish being placed on wire stand with forceps above Sterno® can

pageData.text: Using the forceps, place aluminum dish 1 on top of the wire stand.
Allow the dish to heat for 10 minutes.
Remove the dish from the heat using the forceps, and set the dish aside to cool.
Repeat steps 9–11 for the two remaining samples (aluminum dishes 2 and 3).
Allow the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can to burn to completion and then cool.
After all samples have cooled, weigh the aluminum dishes containing the dehydrated Epsom salt on the balance, and record the values in Data Table 1.
Calculate the masses for the samples of dehydrated Epsom salt, and record the values in the row marked “Epsom salt, heated (dehydrated) mass” in Data Table 1.

Subtract the values for “Epsom salt, heated (dehydrated) mass” from the values for “Epsom salt, original (hydrated) mass” for each sample. This is the mass of water for each sample. Record these values in Data Table 1.
Calculate the moles of magnesium sulfate for each sample and record the values in Data Table 1.
Calculate the moles of water for each sample and record the values in Data Table 1.
Calculate the molar ratio of water to magnesium sulfate for each sample and record the values in Data Table 1.

text: The cooled aluminum weighing dishes, Epsom salt, and Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can may be disposed of in the trash.
Return the balance and forceps to your equipment kit.
Clean the workspace thoroughly with soap and water.

To start the activity, number the three aluminum dishes and add Epsom salt to each dish. Then, determine the mass of the salt in each dish. Next, light a Sterno® heater and place the heater under a wire stand. Heat each dish, then determine the mass of the dehydrated salt in each dish. Finally, calculate the mass of water, moles of magnesium sulfate, and moles of water in each sample, as well as the molar ratio of water to magnesium sulfate.

data.title: Atom
data.content: The smallest unit of an element that retains the chemical properties of that element

data.title: Coefficients
data.content: Number placed before the symbol for an element or the formula for a compound in a chemical equation

data.title: Compound
data.content: A substance that consists of identical molecules composed of two or more elements

data.title: Element
data.content: A pure substance that consists of only one type of atom

data.title: Hydrate
data.content: A particular type of molecule, such as an inorganic salt, which contains water integrated into a solid crystalline structure

data.title: Law of Conservation of Mass
data.content: States that atoms are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical reaction; the changes that occur during any reaction are simply rearrangements of the atoms

data.title: Molecule
data.content: The smallest unit of a compound that retains the chemical properties of that compound

data.title: Product
data.content: A substance produced in a chemical reaction

data.title: Reactants
data.content: Substances consumed in a chemical reaction to generate product

data.title: Subscripts
data.content: Numbers that indicate the number of atoms of a particular element in a molecule
